result.text: Uncovering various paths for environmentally recycling lithium iron phosphate batteries through life cycle assessment

Yuan Tao, Tianyi Sun, Zhuopu Wang. Uncovering various paths for environmentally recycling lithium iron phosphate batteries through life cycle assessment. Journal of Cleaner Production, 393 (2023): 136263. ISSN 0959-6526. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2023.136263
ABSTRACT

In recent years, the rapid development of global new energy vehicle industry has brought severe challenges to the waste management of retired power batteries. How to minimise the environmental impact in the recovery process has become a common and emergent concern. In this study, Life Cycle Assessment Model (LCA) was applied to analyse the entire life cycle of Lithium Iron Phosphate (LFP) batteries from the production, use, and recovery processes and compared the life cycle environmental impacts of different recovery technologies to determine the technology with the optimum overall environmental attributes. The critical process for reducing environmental impacts and the main contributing factors were identified by thoroughly evaluating the environmental impact of the recovery process and the reduction of the environmental impact in the production phase by using recycled products. The results show that the cascade utilisation technique has the optimum performance compared with the all-component physical method and hydrometallurgical recovery technology. The results also imply that the production phase has a relatively greater impact on the assessment results when the recovery phase is not considered, especially the use phase has no contribution to the ADP, while the production phase has a contribution of  $97.8\%$ . Through the comprehensive comparison of different recovery technologies for lithium iron phosphate batteries, it is found that the environmental impact of the recovery phase can be improved by prioritising cascade utilisation, increasing the recovery rate, reducing the resource and energy consumption and pollution discharge in the recovery process, increasing the variety of recycled battery materials, and choosing the recycled products that can substitute for more production steps.
1. Introduction

To combat climate change, the transition to electrification has become a major trend in the transportation sector. In recent years, with the rapid development of global new energy vehicle industry, the output of power batteries, as the core component and power source of electric vehicles (EVs), is also increasing. By 2030, the annual capacity of retired power batteries is estimated to be 100-120 GWh worldwide (Miao et al., 2022). Among many power batteries, lithium iron phosphate (LFP) batteries are widely used to power electric vehicles because of their distinctive characteristics, including safety, relatively long cycle life, environmental friendliness, high energy density, high power density and few maintenance requirements (Scrosati and Garche, 2010; Xu et al., 2012). But power batteries are essentially energy-intensive products leading to significant energy demand and pollution emissions during material extraction, production, use and disposal stages.

The resource demands and environmental impacts associated with power batteries within the life cycle are key challenges that restricted the sustainable development of EVs. It is necessary to evaluate the environmental impact of power batteries in the whole life cycle. With regard to the battery, the life cycle assessment (LCA) is one of the most effective ways of exploring the resource and environmental impact of a battery's life cycle, a system of assessment has been developed by ISO 14040. It includes technical surveys of the battery life cycle stages, from material acquisition and manufacturing to use and end-of-life (Zackrisson et al., 2010).

Based on the LCA model, the environmental impacts of power batteries had been assessed in some studies. Schmidt et al. (2016) observed that upstream processes related to the extraction and beneficiation of cathode materials based on nickel and cobalt have been identified to be associated with largest environmental burdens. Zhao and You (2019) demonstrated that battery cell production is the most significant

contributor to the life cycle pollution emissions. Meanwhile, there are few studies that quantify the environmental impact of power batteries recycling process. Feng et al. (2022) found that battery recycling can reduce the resource and environmental impact by  $5 - 30\%$ , which was an effective means to reduce resource and environmental problems to achieve sustainable development. It could be found that most studies focused more on the battery production and first use phase in power batteries (Majeau-Bettez et al., 2011a,b; Quan et al., 2022), but few studies conducted in-depth analysis of theirs environmental impact that the recycling process exerts. This is mainly because the current power battery recycling technology is not yet mature (Xiao et al., 2019), and there exists some difficulties to obtain actual production data. However, the properly recycling of power batteries can largely reduce the environmental burden during these batteries' whole life cycle. Wang and Yu (2021) used LCA to speculate the environmental impact of lithium-ion battery, and found if waste lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) could be appropriately recycled, their life cycle environmental impact would be further dramatically decreased. Also, power batteries contain abundant metals that have a high economic value for recovery (Fan et al., 2020; Volesky, 1990), and they can trigger environmental pollution and cause pathogenic risks to human health without adequate recycling (Siqi et al., 2019).

Therefore, an assessment based on the LCA is required to specify the environmental impacts of power batteries from a whole life cycle perspective, especially in-depth research on the environmental impacts of power batteries in the recovery process. Echelon use, hydrometallurgical recycling, and pyrometallurgical recycling are the dominating techniques of recovery currently (Lv et al., 2018; Quan et al., 2022). Mohr et al. (2020) used a cell-chemistry specific LCA of LIBs recycling processes, and demonstrated the highest benefit is obtained via advanced hydrometallurgical treatment for lithium nickel manganese cobalt oxide and lithium nickel cobalt aluminum oxide-type batteries, but this analysis did not include LFP batteries. Hao et al. (2017) observed that hydrometallurgical recycling of lithium-ion nickel-cobalt-manganese (NCM) batteries could achieve a  $34\%$  reduction of greenhouse gas emissions, but the comparison of recycling technologies was not carried out. In fact, in most related research, usually only one type of recycling technology is studied, and comparative studies on the LCA of multiple recycling technologies are lacking. Yang et al. (2022) found that the LFP battery was more environmentally friendly in the global warming potential (GWP) and acidification potential (AP), while the NCM battery was more environmentally friendly in abiotic depletion (fossil) (ADP(f)) and human toxicity potential (HTP). The research object included LFP, but environmental impact indices lacked primary energy depletion (PED), eutrophication potential (EP) and environmental in organics (RI). Similarly, Quan et al. (2022) compared different recovery technologies for LFP batteries and concluded that hydrometallurgy was recommended for recycling waste LFP batteries by better environmental advantages than pyrometallurgy and direct physical recycling, but the environmental impact categories shown on recovery technologies were not comprehensive.

Accordingly, this study aims to fulfill the gap to specify the environmental impacts of power batteries through the whole LCA, including that in the recovery process which is usually omitted in existing research; and to comprehensively comprise different recycling technologies and the corresponding environmental impact indices. In addition to echelon use and hydrometallurgical recycling, the novel all-component physical method represented by the recovery process of Beijing Saidemei Resources Recycling Research Institute (Beijing, China) Co., Ltd. is also involved in this study. Specifically, when capacity reaches less than  $80\%$ , decommissioned power batteries can be used in echelon, that is, in other energy storage fields or equipment with low requirements for battery capacity (Zhang et al., 2020). Hydrometallurgy extraction process, or chemical leaching, which is practiced commercially in China, offers a less energy-intensive alternative and lower capital costs. These processes employed regents such as hydrochloric

acid (HCL), nitric acid  $(\mathrm{HNO}_3)$ , sulfuric acid  $(\mathrm{H}_2\mathrm{SO}_4)$ , and hydrogen peroxide  $(\mathrm{H}_2\mathrm{O}_2)$  for extracting and separating cathode metals, generally run below  $100^{\circ}\mathrm{C}$  and can recover lithium in addition to the other transition metals (Jung et al., 2021). The hydrometallurgical process mainly consists of leaching and extraction, which has many advantages such as high extraction efficiency, low energy consumption, little hazardous gas emission, and low capital cost (Lv et al., 2018). The novel all-component physical method refers to the first domestic production line for automatic disassembly, precise separation and all-component material recovery of waste power batteries independently developed by Beijing Saidemei Resource Recycling Research Institute (China Beijing) Co., Ltd. The production line can recover the electrolyte and diaphragm which cannot be recovered by hydrometallurgy, and can truly realize the automatic and accurate separation and collection of all seven raw materials (waste positive powder, waste negative powder, aluminum foil, copper foil powder, electrolyte, diaphragm and battery case) in the battery.

In summary, this study constructs an LCA model to analyse the entire life cycle of LFP batteries from the production, use, and recovery processes and compared the life cycle environmental impacts of different recovery technologies to determine the technology with the optimum overall environmental attributes. With the overall comparison of different recovery technologies, the pros and cons of different technologies and the key links and main contributing factors to reducing the environmental impacts can be further identified. Also, specific measures to improve the environmental performance based on the analysis results are proposed. So that relevant decision-making and technical support can be offered for related green manufacturing and full lifecycle management to help the electric vehicle industry develop more sustainably.

2.3. Methodological logic

In terms of the methodological logic behind it, this research first conducts life cyle inventory analysis through analyzing the list of energy material consumption and environmental pollutant emissions in each process of the production stage, use stage, and the recovery stage. The data involved was obtained through consulting the environmental impacts assessment reports of relevant production enterprises, enterprise patents, national standards, and related documents. In each production link, the end-point pollution control measures taken by the enterprise were considered to reflect the true situation of the enterprise's production and operation status. Some raw material mining and processing data were analysed with the aid of three databases in the LCA software eBalance, which are the China LCA database (CLCD), the Ecoinvent database and the EU ELCD database (Liu et al., 2010). Then, this study

assessed the life cycle environmental impacts of lithium iron phosphate batteries, compared and analysed different recovery technologies, identified the critical processes and main contributing factors, comprehensively evaluated the reduction effects of the recovery phase on the total environmental impact with different recovery technologies, and proposed specific measures for reducing environmental impact based on the assessment results. The indices selected for the life cycle environmental impact assessment of lithium iron phosphate batteries include abiotic depletion potential (ADP), acidification potential (AP), Chinese ADP (CADP), primary energy depletion (PED), eutrophication potential (EP), global warming potential (GWP), and respiratory inorganics (RI). The assessment model of each index was directly obtained from eBalance software. Specifically, the CML2002 model was applied to evaluate AP, EP, and ADP; IPCC2007 was used to assess GWP; and IMPACT2002+ was applied to assess RI.

In the inventory analysis, the energy and material consumption and waste discharge associated with a functional unit of lithium iron phosphate batteries in the production phase will be described in detail. The data were mainly retrieved from the environmental impact assessment reports of the relevant manufacturing enterprises, the enterprises' patents, and related literature (Xi et al., 2017; Yu et al., 2017; Zhang et al., 2017; Xi et al., 2017; Jiao et al., 2017; Li et al., 2017; Zhu and Deng, 2017; Chen and Chen, 2016). Also, the database in eBalance software was referred to obtain certain data on raw material extraction and processing; the end-of-pipe approaches applied by the enterprises were considered in each production step.

3.3. Recovery phase

The recovery technologies of lithium iron phosphate batteries are divided into two categories: cascade utilisation and recycling. As the cathode material of lithium iron phosphate batteries does not contain precious metals, such as nickel, cobalt, and manganese, the recycling technique for spent ternary lithium-ion batteries is not applicable for lithium iron phosphate batteries. Therefore, in addition to the traditional hydrometallurgical recovery method, the novel all-component physical method represented by the recovery process of Beijing Saidemei Resources Recycling Research Institute (Beijing, China) Co., Ltd. was also evaluated for the recycling of lithium iron phosphate batteries in this study. It should be noted that the "physical method" here only refers to a material recovery method, not strictly excluding chemical reactions.
3.3.1. Cascade utilisation technique

The cascade utilisation process of lithium iron phosphate batteries is demonstrated in Fig. 4. Taking BYD's cascade utilisation project for lithium iron phosphate batteries as a reference, the spent lithium iron phosphate battery system is processed into echelon-use battery packs through visual inspection, product components and wiring harness replacement, static measurement, capacity measurement, cell matching, connector assembly inspection, laser welding, cell adjustment, battery case assembly, and packaging inspection. Only a minor amount of waste gas is generated during laser welding in this whole process. The inventory is shown in Table 16.

Another recycling technology for lithium iron phosphate batteries is the all-component physical method. 4. Results and discussion
4.1. Life cycle impact assessment
The indices selected for the life cycle environmental impact

5. Conclusions and recommendations
5.1. Conclusions

This study assessed the life cycle environmental impacts of lithium iron phosphate batteries, compared and analysed different recovery technologies, identified the critical processes and main contributing factors, comprehensively evaluated the reduction effects of the recovery phase on the total environmental impact with different recovery technologies, and proposed specific measures for reducing environmental impact based on the assessment results.

(1) The cascade utilisation technique has the most optimum performance, followed by the two recycling technologies, the all-component physical method and hydrometallurgical recovery technology. As for the two recycling technologies, the environmental impact of the all-component physical method is less than that of the hydrometallurgical recovery technique, with relatively lower values for all indices, especially the ADP and AP. When the recovery phase is not considered, the production phase has a relatively greater impact on the assessment results. For example, the use phase has no contribution to the ADP, while the production phase has a contribution of  $97.8\%$ ; the production phase contributes to  $77.4\%$  of the AP, and the use phase has a

contribution of  $22.6\%$ . The production processes of cathode material and copper foil are the main contributing steps in the production phase, with ferric phosphate and copper as the main contributing substances. In general, the percentage contribution of the use phase of lithium iron phosphate batteries to the indices is lower than that of the production phase, except for the primary energy consumption and GWP.

The results of this study are more comprehensive than the LCA findings in existing literature, as almost no literatures have studied the all-component physical method. Feng et al. (2022) used the ReCiPe 2016 Midpoint method to perform a cradle-to-grave Life Cycle Assessment for NCM and LFP batteries, and they concluded the hydrometallurgical recycling provides better comprehensive characteristics in the battery recycling process in general, ensuring efficient recycling while taking into account the environmental impact. Quan et al. (2022) concluded hydrometallurgy outperformed pyrometallurgy and direct physical recycling environmentally. But this study found that the cascade utilisation technique has the optimum performance, followed by the two recycling technologies, the all-component physical method and hydrometallurgical recovery technology. As different studies focus on different index or factors, such as battery chemistries, modelling approach used for the pyrometallurgical and hydrometallurgical process etc., corresponding results are accordingly different.

(2) The environmental impact of the different recovery technologies in the recovery process ranks as all-component physical method  $>$  hydrometallurgical recovery technology  $>$  cascade utilisation technique. Among them, the critical step of the all-component physical method is material recovery, and the main contributing substance is electric energy; the key steps of the hydrometallurgical recovery technology are slurrying and acid leaching and transformation and washing, and the main contributing substance is hydrochloric acid. The reduction of the environmental impact of the production phase by the recycled products of different recovery technologies ranks as hydrometallurgical recovery technology  $<$  all-component physical method  $<$  cascade utilisation technique. For example, the recycled product of cascade utilisation can offset the highest proportion of

the AP in the production phase (96.64%). The recycled products of the all-component physical method can cumulatively offset 91.17% of the AP in the production phase, with the percentage contribution of copper foil recovery being the largest (68.68%). The proportion of the AP in the production phase offset by the recycled product of the hydrometallurgical recovery technology is the smallest (1.07%). In general, the cascade utilisation technique can reduce the total environmental impact to the largest extent, followed by the all-component physical method, and the reduction of total environmental impact by the hydrometallurgical recovery technology is the minimum.
(3) For lithium iron phosphate batteries, in addition to the production phase, the environmental impact of the use phase is also considerably significant. As the environmental impact of this phase is only sourced from electric energy consumption, the usage of electric energy and the cleanliness of energy sources are critical to the assessment results. In terms of reducing electric energy consumption, increasing the energy density of the battery system to reduce its overall weight, decreasing the energy consumption level of the battery during the driving process, and increasing the charge-discharge efficiency can minimise electric power loss. For the cleanliness of electric energy sources, if the resource and energy consumption and the pollution level associated with electric power generation can be reduced, the environmental impact of the batteries' use phase can be remarkably decreased.

Quan et al. (2022) also revealed that by optimizing the charge-discharge efficiency of LFP batteries, all environmental burdens could be considerably decreased, and they concluded that improving the electrochemical performance of LFP batteries and increasing the use proportion of clean energy were crucial to reduce the environmental impacts over their entire life cycle. The above conclusions are consistent with those of this study.

In terms of the environmental impact of the recovery phase, the application of the cascade utilisation technique should be assigned high priority to the spent lithium iron phosphate batteries to minimise the environmental impact of their entire life cycle. Different recovery technologies can help improve the environmental impact of the recovery phase by raising the recovery rate, reducing the resource and energy consumption and pollution discharge in the recovery process, increasing the variety of recycled battery materials, and choosing the recycled products that can be substituted for more production steps.
5.2. Limitations and recommendations

There still exists some limitations in this research. This study emphasizes on the recovery phase while conducting the LCA of lithium iron phosphate batteries, but in fact there exists a variety of technologies in the battery production stage. In the meantime, the environmental impact in the use phase largely related to the source of electric energy.

Therefore, further research is recommended to synthetically analyse different production technologies, different sources of electric energy, and different recycling technologies throughout the whole life cycle of lithium iron phosphate batteries, from the production phase to the use phase, and to the recovery phase. Incorporating economic factors such as cost is also recommended to provide evidence for each phase in the whole industrial chain of power batteries.

In further power battery recycling and utilisation management, a principle of considering cascade utilisation first and then recycling needs to be followed to largely support cascade utilisation. When making policies regarding batteries' recycling and recovery technologies, the importance should be attached to the resource and energy consumption and pollution emission of different technologies. Categories of recycled products and the corresponding recovery rate should be specified in detail. For the healthy and sustainable development of power battery
recycling, the extended producer responsibility system needs to be well implemented and a sound and efficient recycling system needs to be established as soon as possible.
